The “Friends of the ABC” is a group of young revolutionary students who play a major role in the novel Les Misérables by Victor Hugo. They are also known as the “ABC Society,” which stands for “Les Amis de l’ABC” in French. They are motivated by their desire to overthrow the French government and establish a more just and equal society, inspired by the principles of the French Revolution.

The role of the “Friends of the ABC” is to represent the idealistic and youthful aspect of the revolutionary movement. They are portrayed as passionate and determined young men who are willing to risk everything for their cause. They are also shown as being somewhat naive and inexperienced, as they underestimate the power and brutality of the government forces they are up against.

The members of the “Friends of the ABC” play a key role in the June Rebellion, which was a failed attempt to overthrow the French government in 1832. Despite their defeat, however, their spirit and ideals continued to inspire future generations of revolutionary movements. The “Friends of the ABC” thus represent the ideal of revolution and the belief in the power of ordinary people to create a better world.
